text: Hyōgo Prefecture is a prefecture in the Kansai region of Japan on the island of Honshu.Nussbaum, Louis-Frédéric. (2005). "Hyōgo prefecture" in Japan Encyclopedia, pp. 363-365; "Kansai" at p. 477. The capital city is Kobe.Nussbaum, "Kobe" at p. 537. == History == In the Meiji period, Hyōgo Prefecture was formed by merging the provinces of Harima, Tajima, Awaji, and parts of Tamba and Settsu.Nussbaum, "Provinces and prefectures" at p. 780. In 1993, Himeji Castle was named a UNESCO World Heritage Site. It is in the city of Himeji.Japan-i.jp, Himeji-jo. Retrieved 2012-8-30. In 1995, the Great Hanshin earthquake damaged Kobe and neighboring Osaka Prefecture. It caused the deaths of 5,000+ people.Fukushima, Glen S. "The Great Hanshin Earthquake," Japan Policy Research Institute (JPRI), March 1995. Retrieved 2012-8-30. == Geography == Hyōgo has coastlines on two seas. The Sea of Japan is north of the prefecture and the Seto Inland Sea is on the south. Awaji Island in the Inland Sea is part of Hyōgo. Hyōgo shares land borders with Osaka Prefecture, Kyoto Prefecture, Tottori Prefecture and Okayama Prefecture. ===Cities=== There are twenty-nine cities in Hyōgo Prefecture, including *Aioi *Akashi *Akō *Amagasaki *Asago *Ashiya *Awaji *Himeji *Itami *Kakogawa *Kasai *Katō *Kawanishi *Kobe (capital) :Chūō-ku :Higashinada-ku :Hyōgo-ku :Kita-ku :Nada- ku :Nagata-ku :Nishi-ku :Suma-ku :Tarumi-ku *Miki *Minamiawaji *Nishinomiya *Nishiwaki *Ono *Sanda *Sasayama *Shisō *Sumoto *Takarazuka *Takasago *Tamba *Tatsuno *Toyooka *Yabu ===National Parks=== National Parks are established in about 20% of the total land area of the prefecture.Japan Ministry of the Environment, "General overview of area figures for Natural Parks by prefecture".
